The structural, electronic, and optical properties of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction were analyzed using first-principles calculations, and the effects of biaxial strains on its band structure and optical absorption were also investigated. The results show that the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction exhibits an indirect bandgap of 1.05 eV and non-trivial band overlap, which facilitates efficient charge separation and transport. Differential charge density analysis reveals charge transfer at the interface, forming an intrinsic electric field that enhances the separation of photogenerated carriers and thereby improves photocatalytic performance. The Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction aligns with the S-scheme heterojunction model, enabling effective separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Optical analysis shows significant light absorption in the UV and visible regions, with a redshift compared to monolayer materials. The predicted solar-to-hydrogen (STH) conversion efficiency of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction reaches 55.20 %, highlighting its potential for photocatalytic hydrogen production. Surface modification through elemental doping optimizes hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction, ensuring exothermic reactions. Under alkaline conditions, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction is spontaneous. Biaxial strain tuning further optimizes the bandgap and optical absorption properties of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction, thereby enhancing its photocatalytic performance. The research provides highly potential candidate materials for exploring efficient hydrogen evolution catalysts. Introduction As the global population continues to rise and fossil fuel reserves deplete, the energy crisis has become increasingly severe [1,2]. In the context, the study of semiconductor materials that can enhance energy efficiency has become critically important [3,4]. Semiconductor photocatalysis technology has garnered significant attention due to its ability to efficiently and conveniently utilize solar energy to address the energy crisis [5–9]. Photocatalytic water splitting into hydrogen and oxygen using semiconductor materials can efficiently harness solar energy [10–13]. Therefore, the development of new photocatalysts that are both efficient and stable has become a hot topic in the research field [14]. Over the years, researchers have been dedicated to finding stable and efficient heterojunction photocatalysts [15–17]. Since the successful isolation and study of graphene, researchers have increasingly focused on such two-dimensional materials [18,19]. Many two-dimensional materials with structures similar to graphene, such as hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) [20,21], two-dimensional MXenes, transition metal dichalcogenides [22], and Janus MXY materials [23], have attracted significant attention because of their special electronic transport properties and large surface areas, providing more reactive sites for intermediates during the water splitting process. Since the successful synthesis of MXenes by Yury Gogotsi et al. in 2011 [24], two-dimensional MXenes have attracted great interest due to their unique physicochemical properties and broad applications in supercapacitors [25], batteries [26], sensors [27], catalysis [28], and optoelectronics [29]. Hf2CO2, as a classical MXene material, has low thermal expansion coefficient, high carrier mobility, and high thermal conductivity [30], making it promising for applications in optoelectronics [31], solar cells [32], and gas sensors [33]. Due to the unique properties of Hf2CO2, heterostructures incorporating Hf2CO2 have also been widely studied for applications in optoelectronic devices. For example, Hf2CO2/MoS2 [34], Hf2CO2/WS2 [35], and Hf2CO2/GaN [36] heterostructures have been proposed as potential photocatalysts with suitable band structures and high carrier mobility. Recently, IV-VI based monolayers have also garnered widespread attention, such as GaS, GeS, SiS2, and InSe [37–39]. SiS2 monolayer is a new type of VI-IV two-dimensional material [40]. SiS2 monolayers exhibit energy, dynamic, and thermal stability. The band gap and optical properties of SiS2 can be tuned by external strain [41]. Therefore, SiS2 has great potential in nanophotonic devices. Although two-dimensional materials have advantages over traditional three-dimensional photocatalysts in photocatalysis, in monolayer two-dimensional photocatalysts, both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) occur on the same surface of the material, which may lead to more recombination between the carriers and photogenerated carriers involved in the reactions, thus reducing catalytic efficiency [42]. In short, while two-dimensional materials show great potential in photocatalysis due to their unique properties, they also face the issue of carrier recombination during catalysis, which requires further research to resolve. In recent years, researchers have been committed to developing efficient heterojunction photocatalysts [43–47] and have employed various strategies to overcome the challenges mentioned above, including doping [48], surface modification [49], and heterojunction construction [50,51], to address the above issues. Among them, the van der Waals interactions between the layers of heterostructures can preserve the excellent properties of the individual materials, while the interlayer coupling may lead to even better physical properties. With the successful preparation of heterojunctions such as Fe2O3/g-C3N4 [52], In2S3/g-C3N4 [53], LaNiO3/g-C3N4 [54], MoSe2/g-C3N4 [55], WS2/g-C3N4 [56], MoS2/g-C3N4 [57], and ZnS/g-C3N4 [58], the results showed that heterojunctions can further enhance the photocatalytic performance of the system. These studies indicate that constructing heterostructures can effectively improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers and enhance photocatalytic activity. Based on the excellent properties of the above two monolayers, the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction was constructed and its photocatalytic performance was studied. The photocatalytic potential of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction was explored by investigating its stability, band structure, work function, differential charge density, band alignment, light absorption coefficient, photocatalytic hydrogen evolution efficiency, as well as the reaction activities of HER and OER. Additionally, the band structure and light absorption coefficient of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction were investigated to determine whether they could be optimized through the application of biaxial strain. It is hoped that the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction can combine the advantages of both monolayers, reduce the recombination of electron-hole carriers, and improve the photocatalytic efficiency, providing new solutions for energy conversion and environmental purification. Computational method First-principles calculations based on density functional theory (DFT) were performed using the VASP software package [59]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) method [59] and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [60] were employed to describe electron interactions. The plane-wave cutoff energy was set to 500 eV, and the Brillouin zone was sampled using the Gamma-point scheme. During structural optimization of the 2D materials, the lattice constant along the c-axis was kept fixed, while the lattice constants in the ab plane and atomic positions were fully relaxed. The convergence criteria for energy and force were set to 1 × 10–5 eV and 0.01 eV/Å, respectively. Given the tendency of the PBE functional to underestimate semiconductor bandgaps, the Hybrid Screened Exchange 06 (HSE06) was employed for more accurate calculations of band structures and band edge positions for both monolayer materials and heterojunctions. To eliminate spurious interactions between periodic layers, a 20 Å vacuum layer was introduced along the z-direction. The setup effectively prevents interlayer coupling due to periodic boundary conditions, ensuring the accuracy of the computational results. The inclusion of the vacuum layer helps achieve reliable and precise results by excluding potential coupling effects between adjacent layers. Electronic properties The lattice structures and electronic band structures of the isolated monolayers Hf2CO2 and SiS2 were first analyzed. The optimized structures of Hf2CO2 and SiS2 monolayers are shown in Fig. 1 (a) and 1(b). The lattice constants of the Hf2CO2 and SiS2 monolayers are 3.26 Å and 3.36 Å, respectively. Hf2CO2 is identified as an indirect bandgap semiconductor, with a bandgap of 1.74 eV calculated using the HSE06 functional. Similarly, the SiS2 monolayer also exhibits an indirect bandgap, with a bandgap value of 2.27 eV obtained from HSE06 calculations. These results align well with previous experimental and theoretical findings [30,61], confirming the reliability of the computational methods and data employed in the study. Before constructing the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction, selecting a lattice-matched model was the primary consideration. The lattice constants of the Hf2CO2 and SiS2 monolayers are 3.26 Å and 3.36 Å, respectively, which satisfy the minimal lattice mismatch principle for direct stacking, as illustrated in Fig. 1(c)-(e). For the photocatalytic property calculations, a 3 × 3 supercell expansion was applied to prevent interatomic interactions from affecting the computational results, as shown in Fig. 1(f). The approach ensures accuracy by minimizing potential artifacts arising from periodic boundary conditions. Next, the elastic constants of monolayer Hf2CO2, SiS2, and the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction were measured using the stress-strain method to determine whether they are mechanically stable under in-plane strain [62]. Carrier mobility represents a crucial physical parameter for assessing carrier transport in semiconductors. The mobility is calculated using the deformation potential theory and Boltzmann transport theory. The calculations were simplified by neglecting interactions between electrons and phonons, as well as electron-electron interactions, leading to some degrees of deviations in the results. In contrast, Boltzmann transport theory accounts for electron interactions, yielding more accurate results, though at the expense of significantly longer computation time [66]. The carrier mobility of the 2D materials is calculated based on the deformation potential theory. The carrier mobility of 2D materials is expressed as: (3) μ 2 D = 2 e h 3 C 2 D 3 k B T | m * | 2 E 1 2 In the equation, e represents the electronic charge, h is the reduced Planck constant, C2D denotes the elastic modulus of the uniformly deformed crystal, kB is the Boltzmann constant, T represents the temperature, m* is the effective mass, and El refers to the deformation potential constant of holes at the VBM or electrons at the CBM along the transport direction. The elastic modulus C2D is given as [66]: (4) C 2 D = C 11 2 − C 12 2 C 11 The average effective mass of the carriers md is defined as [66]: (5) m d = m x * * m y * By calculating the effective mass, average effective mass, deformation potential, and elastic modulus, the carrier mobility can be obtained. To obtain the carrier mobility, the effective mass for monolayer Hf2CO2, monolayer SiS2, and the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction was first calculated, from which the average effective mass was derived. Then, a uniaxial strain ranging from −1.5 % to +1.5 % was applied to these three materials along the x and y directions to determine the deformation potential constant El. By analyzing the linear variation in the relative position of the VBM and CBM with respect to the vacuum level, the total energy for each strain condition was fitted to obtain the elastic modulus C2D. The results are shown in Table 1. For monolayer Hf2CO2, the electron and hole deformation potentials El are 4.3 eV and 3.2 eV, respectively, and the elastic modulus C2D is 270.31 J/m2. For monolayer SiS2, the electron and hole deformation potentials El are 5.6 eV and 1.2 eV, respectively, and the elastic modulus C2D is 108.08 J/m2. For the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction, the electron and hole deformation potentials El are 5.4 eV and 3.5 eV, respectively, and the elastic modulus C2D is 373.39 J/m2. These results show that the elastic constant of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction is the largest among the three, indicating that the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction has higher structural stability, which helps resist chemical and photo-corrosion during photocatalysis, thereby improving the material's long-term stability and service life, laying the foundation for further material optimization and application. Typically, when monolayers of Hf2CO2 and SiS2 come into contact, three main carrier transfer pathways exist: first, electrons transition from the CBM of Hf2CO2 to the CBM of SiS2; second, holes move from the VBM of SiS2 to the VBM of Hf2CO2; finally, electron-hole (e-h) pairs are formed at the interface due to interlayer coupling and radiatively recombine. Theoretically, there is a competition between carrier separation in pathways ① and ② and recombination in pathway ③. If the separation rate exceeds the recombination rate, photoexcited electrons and holes will rapidly separate and localize at the CBM of SiS2 and the VBM of Hf2CO2, respectively, exhibiting typical type-II heterojunction behavior. In contrast, if the recombination rate in pathway ③ is greater than the separation rates in pathways ① and ②, photoexcited electrons at the CBM of SiS2 will tend to recombine with holes at the VBM of Hf2CO2, forming an S-scheme pathway. In Fig. 4, due to the difference in charge distribution at the interface, the separation rate of photogenerated carriers is slowed under the influence of the electric field, while the recombination rate of photogenerated carriers in the middle layer is accelerated. Additionally, the band bending shows distinct characteristics due to Coulomb forces. The energy bands of Hf₂CO₂ bend upward, while those of SiS₂ bend downward, creating a potential barrier between the conduction band (CB) of Hf₂CO₂ and the valence band (VB) of SiS₂, effectively suppressing the occurrence of pathways ① and ②. However, the band bending at the VBM of Hf₂CO₂ and the CBM of SiS₂ favors the occurrence of pathway ③. This distinct band bending results in the spatial separation of photogenerated electrons and holes in the Hf₂CO₂ and SiS₂ layers, respectively. The photogenerated electrons in the CB of Hf₂CO₂ move towards the HER site, while the holes in the VB of SiS₂ move towards the OER site, resulting in an effective carrier separation mechanism that aligns with the S-scheme heterojunction model. In an S-scheme heterojunction, the electron-hole pairs are effectively separated and confined to the respective materials, ensuring that electron transfer for the HER occurs in Hf2CO2, while hole transfer for the OER occurs in SiS2. This mechanism is fundamentally different from the Z-scheme, where electrons and holes are transferred via a direct route, often involving two separate materials with different energy levels. In the case of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction, the presence of an additional potential barrier and the internal electric field enhances the carrier separation efficiency without allowing the direct recombination of electrons and holes, which would occur in a Z-scheme. Conclusion The electronic properties and photocatalytic characteristics of the two-dimensional Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction were explored using first-principles calculations based on density functional theory, and the impacts of biaxial strain on its performance were also explored. The results show that the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction exhibits excellent stability, with a bandgap of 1.05 eV. The high carrier mobility of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction effectively reduces the recombination rate of electron-hole pairs. The built-in electric field in the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction facilitates the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and effectively prevents recombination. Furthermore, the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction demonstrates superior light absorption capacity, with a predicted photocatalytic hydrogen production efficiency significantly higher than that of the two monolayer materials, reaching 55.20 %. Gibbs free energy calculations show that for the HER, surface doping modification results in a ΔGH of −0.09 eV, indicating that the HER can occur spontaneously and that hydrogen adsorption and desorption are both favorable. In the OER, under alkaline conditions and light irradiation, the reaction can proceed spontaneously. By applying appropriate strain, the bandgap and light absorption properties of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction can be tuned to optimize its photocatalytic performance. In conclusion, the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction not only demonstrates outstanding photocatalytic hydrogen production potential in theory but also represents a promising photocatalyst. coredata.dc:description: The structural, electronic, and optical properties of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction were analyzed using first-principles calculations, and the effects of biaxial strains on its band structure and optical absorption were also investigated. The results show that the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction exhibits an indirect bandgap of 1.05 eV and non-trivial band overlap, which facilitates efficient charge separation and transport. Differential charge density analysis reveals charge transfer at the interface, forming an intrinsic electric field that enhances the separation of photogenerated carriers and thereby improves photocatalytic performance. The Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction aligns with the S-scheme heterojunction model, enabling effective separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Optical analysis shows significant light absorption in the UV and visible regions, with a redshift compared to monolayer materials. The predicted solar-to-hydrogen (STH) conversion efficiency of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction reaches 55.20 %, highlighting its potential for photocatalytic hydrogen production. Surface modification through elemental doping optimizes hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activity of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction, ensuring exothermic reactions. Under alkaline conditions, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction is spontaneous. Biaxial strain tuning further optimizes the bandgap and optical absorption properties of the Hf2CO2/SiS2 heterojunction, thereby enhancing its photocatalytic performance. The research provides highly potential candidate materials for exploring efficient hydrogen evolution catalysts.
